comments.commentBody: If players want to own a franchise, what are they waiting for? A discount?
I was going to try to save the situation with something about Rings around Rabaul Julia, but this is beyond rescue.
Someone help me please.

I'm sorry, but this is just incorrect, and I cannot let it stand. Hailey, ID cancelled the homecoming celebration because they were worried about how many people--and how much trouble--this new kerfuffle would cause in their town. Have you ever been there? The shape, topography, and size of the town would make for a logistical nightmare for big crowds--especially angry ones.

They did NOT cancel the celebration because "the facts became known." Very few facts are known at this point.
with the apache helicotpers flying over head I would think they would.  Its just like a pardon my saying ... drug deal...anything and everything can go wrong.

And of all those countries who abhorred the Taliban, who was the one to take it upon themselves to "fix" the situation. There are "legitimate" governments all over the world that do horrible things we would never do. The question is, are we so morally superior that we are justified in invading and killing that government? NO! We are not! Especially since our government isn't exactly Jesus Christ on a Cracker.

Back in the real cowboy days, most folks didn't carry them.  Owning a handgun was illegal in Texas during most of the "wild west" era, though vendors would circumvent the law by leasing handguns to customers.  On the cattle drives (that existed for only about 20 years btw) the company had rifles and pistols that were kept usually in the chuck wagon to be distributed when a situation warranted, but most of the drovers were inexpert as they seldom used weapons themselves.

Carry on. Carry on. Children I say. I won't take a car trip through Oklahoma from my Kansas home. I'd rather drive completely around it so I don't have to look at the armed cowboys. Hey, back in the real cowboy days, most folks didn't carry them around to look menacing.

Agreed. Holding him out as a hero was just miscalculated.
Can this President hire a PR firm to let him know what AMERICANS are thinking since it is such a mystery to him.

This soldier is either mentally ill for leaving his post or deserted his post for a better life there ( mentally ill again too with that thought.). It should have been a quiet affair, we rescued him and he is seeking the health care in a hospital and dealing with probably a military trial to determine what happened when he left.
he was there for 6 weeks before he left. To have ptsd it has to be post something, Bergdhal wasn't there long enough.

I spoke to a retiring Army Special Forces colonel last weekend when the news broke. I asked him what he thought about the Bergdahl release (since I knew very little of the details). He said that he hoped they brought him home and courtmartialed him for desertion. He mentioned that he walked off after leaving his items and had asked kids which way the Taliban was. And that six soldiers died looking for him.

This was not partisan media spin, just information from someone in the know, well before this information went viral. I think they should do an inquiry, and I think based on what I am seeing, that he will be court martialed - and should be. To let him off should an inquiry hear all the facts would be critically damaging for the moral of those who do their duty that they swore an oath to perform (and yes, I served in the military - and I have no political affiliations).

As for John McCain, he was shot down over Vietnam, he did not walk off into the desert. I think he was "on duty" when he was shot down and I personally think your equating the experience of the two is shameful.

You are obviously unable to recognize that physicians caring for your father might have done nothing wrong and might perform up to the current medical best practices standards even when not able to immediately diagnoze and thus provide effective treatment.

Compared to some years ago medicine is able to deliver "miracles" on daily basis and in millions of cases. Physicians, nurses, etc. need to learn so huge and massively exploding volume of information: microbiology being the most expanding filed as far as new discoveries and changes is concerned.

I do not know what profession you are in or what knowledge base your job requires you to have to perform your work on daily basis well but you tend tio get accross as highly subjective, not much educated complainer.

JK - I agree wholeheartedly with your comments. Patients like K.R. are ubiquitous on these NYT pages, uninformed but bellicose in their demanding, diminishing, demeaning, nasty negativity.

Yes, it is more than difficult that a loved one suffered. A more appropriate target to blame for the "7-minute environment" might be the insurance and hospital industry types. rather than your father's team of physicians and nurses. Most of them enter the medical field out of a desire to help others, taking to heart that sorrow when treatments fail, despite their best effort for the patient.

I'm reassured by the replies to KR. I've perceived a tremendous animosity and mistrust of doctors (mostly online, less in real-life). It convinced me that better communication between patients and providers is helpful because education can sometimes clear up these misunderstandings and prevent the misinformed from being critical in public later on. However, all of this backlash toward a group of people who believe in science, aren't getting rich from it, and are trying to do the right thing is pretty disappointing. It's hard to convince the lay public how hard medicine really is. If it was easy, we'd all be physicians.

My father had encephalitis several years ago and we watched him slip into a coma over the course of a week. It was the most terrifying experience because on the way, he lost his ability to communicate, to reason, he hallucinated, didn't recognize us, had to be restrained, all of his vitals went haywire. Something I will never forget. It was a race against the clock.

Doctors only sit by the bedside (like Dr. House) on television. They are in the habit of ordering tests and coming back the next day to interpret the results. They don't get paid to hang around. So a DNA test like this is invaluable.
In my father's case, he was on every antibiotic, but needed the antiviral Acyclovir because he had Herpes Encephalitis. We expect Doctors to know everything, but when something is outside the box (especially in today's 7-minute environment) it's difficult for them. Often they get stuck in an algorithm and can't let go. Ego can get in the way too.
I had a lot of anger because the delay in treatment resulted in disability and a lot of suffering (my suffering too, as caregiver). But I have forgiven.

Taking the guesswork out of diagnosing difficult cases will save a lot of lives. This is great news. So wonderful to read that this young man had a positive outcome.
Is there any indication of how the boy acquired the infection? An animal bite perhaps?

How about some actual evidence, e.s. - all you are doing is making a bunch of assertions without providing any proof. State department and other US government officials are maintaining an embassy and all the rest that goes along with a diplomatic mission. What mercenaries are US tax dollars being spent on in Ukraine? Ypu do have some actual proof of that.

You have no evidence that an order was given to attack civilians. The supposed airstrike was no doubt an error on the pilot's part. Do you condemn the US for the hundreds of civilians killed in it's targeted drone strikes? There the effect was more intentional disregard for civilians in very intentional air strikes and the fact that civilians were killed by mistake can also be called criminal negligence and certainly negates the argument that they are precise, accurate strikes aimed only at terrorists..
Why don't you check some facts before forming an opinion, especially such a categorical one. Ironically, the less informed are always the loudest...
Was wondering the same thing, and looks like everyone else and their brother were too. What gives?  "This technology allows us to see the world in a different way" - !

I totally disagree.  The cases for which this technology is applicable is so sparse that there is absolutely NO money to be made.  In order to make money one needs to have VOLUME and PRICING.  Isolated cases will NEVER make money.  One has to distinguish true medical breakthrough for difficult (but rare) cases versus incremental progress for the masses (where money IS made).

What is insulting is State Department officials plotting to install a puppet regime in a sovereign country. That conversation does not need to be "mischaracterized", it's speaks for itself (unintended pun).
Leptospira is most classically transmitted through unpasteurized dairy. I don't disagree with proper animal husbandry, but you can't vaccinate against leptospira. And we don't milk dogs and pigs.
Same as the US and UK use Voice  of America and BBC ( both state controlled and financed). I guess Russia is just a good student.

I suppose they "could" make those decisions, but I don't think they will because they would be dumb decisions, causing more harm than good. Some people need the elevator to stop at every floor (people using wheelchairs, people with sprained ankles, some elderly people, people with strollers, people delivering things or carrying boxes, people with shopping or laundry carts....) and it is not the case that most adults need to go to bed at 9 or even 10 o'clock. But what is the downside to not drinking 20 oz sodas in one serving? Can't think of one.

what is the upside of banning a 20 oz soda? Do you really believe that this will limit the number of obese people? Reverse the obesity 'trend?' It will not. Obesity is cause more by eathing high glycemic foods, it's not sugar, it's starch and 'how' one's body converts it to fat or energy. Everyone has different metabolisms. Older people have slower metabolisms, but they aren't cruizing NYC with 20 oz sodas. Children have higher metabolisms, but with no physical education in schools for the last 25 years (never understood why that was eliminated), many kids have no excersize in their life.

Guess we should outlaw video games and iphones in an effort to guide the populous towards activity?

Yes, there is a downsize to making laws about the size of a food package that can be sold/purchased.

The City Board of Health banned lead paint in the 1950s (while it was still lawful conduct to paint with it through the 1970s) so you're argument simply ignores the precedent and the facts.

Your elevator analogy is really not comparable as a structural and transportation element within a building like an elevator is simply not the same as a food product that people are buying which is making them unhealthier (and which we are all paying for in the end).

The Board of Health is still accountable to voters because it is part of the city's executive branch and answerable to the mayor (an elected official). You have a problem with what the Board does, then vote for a new mayor.

This case isn't about the merits of a large-serving soda ban. It's about whether an unelected administrative agency can ban otherwise lawful conduct in an effort to encourage healthier lifestyles and I believe that the Board of Health does not (and should not) have that power.
Could the Board of Health ban elevators in an effort to make us climb stairs and be more active? Or mandate that they stop only on every third floor? Or require that restaurants, bars, theaters and other public venues close by 9 pm in order to encourage us to get enough sleep? If any public body has the authority to make these kinds of decisions it should be one that is elected (e.g., the State Legislature or City Council) so that its members know that they will be accountable to voters for their decisions.

There is also no evidence that obesity is related solely to soda pop consumption -- there are plenty of fat people who drink no soda, or drink only diet soda -- or who drink heavily sweetened iced tea or coffee drinks, none of which were affected by the proposed law.

The things one could potentially "get fat on" range from donuts to goulash, and a million things in between -- including expensive gourmet luxuries. If this were a serious law, it would have to ban and micromanage millions of different food items, and THEN intrude into people's lives to be sure they didn't "sneak" stuff or buy food on a sure-to-exist black market.

It's nanny-stating gone berserk.

That would only be true if you could establish scientifically and provably that banning soda (or even restricting) would result in people becoming significantly thinner or in lower rates of diabetes. But you cannot, because there is no direct causation.

I was born in the 50s, and I remember LOTS of overweight and obese people, so your perceptions are likely very off.

The "preview" is of your future chance to get Type II diabetes -- and it won't matter what you eat. Because it's hereditary and linked to age.

Even if you remain normal weight, you are at risk of becoming diabetic after age 60. If you are seriously overweight, you may (MAY) get it earlier, but the chances are great that you cannot avoid diabetes no matter what you eat.

You make a very good point. We don't want bureaucrats coopting the power of the legislature. On the other hand, I don't see what business it is of the legislature to control how much soda someone drinks.
